sentence.text: Case 3 is a second cousin of the propositus.
He was born at 9 months of gestation by a normal delivery, with a birth weight of 2,920 g (10–25th centile) and a length of 43.2 cm (<3rd centile).
He began walking at 15 months, had a waddling gait and cried frequently.
He gained weight poorly, had a poor appetite, and easy fatigability.
At age 6 years, he had lower limb pain and fatigue after walking half a block.
He was at the 35th centile for height and <5th centile for weight.

He had frontal bossing, small teeth with thin enamel, mild hepatomegaly, markedly pronated, externally rotated feet, decreased muscle mass and tone, hypoactive reflexes and dry, scaly skin with poor turgor.
His ESR was 40 mm/h; serum calcium, phosphorus, and alkaline phosphatase were normal.
Radiographs showed cortical thickening with irregular areas of density in the upper and lower limbs, especially the femora.
There was a slight increase in the density of the skull.
The spine, pelvis, and ribs were normal.
The bone age was 3½ years at age 6 years.
A biopsy of the right tibia by report showed no changes in the marrow with a thin layer of fibrous tissue along the inner surface of the dense, outer, cortical bone.
He was diagnosed with Albers–Schönberg disease.
By age 8 years he continued to have poor muscular development and marked weakness.
He was at the 20th centile for height and <5th centile for weight.
His head circumference was 57 cm (>98th centile).
He also had severe genua valga.
At age 10 years he reported hearing loss.
The skull had increased density along the floor of the anterior and middle fossa, there was increased sclerosis in the femora and both forearms were now affected.
A diagnosis of osteopetrosis was suspected.
At age 17½ years he had limited mobility of the shoulders, thoracolumbar scoliosis, and flexion contractures of both knees.
He had hyperhidrosis of the hands and feet.
He underwent bilateral tibial and fibular osteotomies followed by bilateral femoral supracondylar osteotomies to correct his lower limb deformities.
Histologic examination of the bone by report showed a thickened periosteum without evidence of inflammation and thickened vessel walls.
The cortex showed a dense compact structure, normal haversian systems, and minimal osteoblast and osteoclast activity.
At age 20 years, he had normal peripheral nerve conduction and EMG.
A biopsy of the right fibular epiphysis showed, by report, markedly osteoporotic bone and a normal epiphyseal plate with minimal proliferative activity.
A muscle biopsy was normal.
He developed tinnitus, hearing impairment in the right ear, episodic vertigo, and right facial paresis.
He was diagnosed with PDD at age 21 years, following the diagnosis of his second cousin.
Five years later, he had right upper facial paralysis, right lower facial paresis, progressive hearing loss, and balance problems.
Radiographs showed massive overgrowth of bone involving the petrous apex and mastoid bones partially obstructing both internal auditory canals.
The entire skull base was markedly thickened with increased density of the inner and outer tables.
Bilateral decompressions of the internal auditory canals and middle cranial fossa were performed.
Hearing in the left ear improved slightly initially, then it gradually deteriorated.
At age 47 years his internal auditory canals were nearly entirely obliterated by bone.
At age 54 years, he had marked deviation of the nasal septum and nasal obstruction.
He underwent septostomy.
He was diagnosed with hyposmia suspected to be due to hyperostosis of the cribiform plate and olfactory region.
At age 60 years, he had severe limb pain, prominence of the distal femora bilaterally, quadriceps wasting, weakness, tinnitus, and intermittent headache.
He walked short distances with crutches.
He had a prominent right mandible, right complete facial palsy, left upper facial palsy, deviation of the palate to the right, and deviation of tongue to the left.
Radiographs of his limbs, skull, and pelvis showed severe hyperostosis of his skull and long bones (Fig. 1).
He declined steroid therapy secondary to the fear of side effects.
